I mean, we saw – if I look at your doubtful loans numbers, they were remarkably static really last year, just creeping up ever so slightly as the year wore on. Yet when I look at the first quarter numbers, there seems to be a bit of a jump, and it's – I mean, I'm not suggesting it's Spain sort of type levels, but it does seem to have shot up in the first quarter. And at the same time, the collateral relation to loans written down also seems to have shot up.

I was just wondering if you could give us a little bit more color on what you're seeing with that jump in doubtful loans? Whether it's something that's due with a change in accounting, or it's the seasonality? Or whether there is a pool of new loans sort of becoming doubtful that perhaps might give us an early warning? Thanks.

Thank you. On the long-term funding, I make a good note of what you've said. Here again, we have not really made our mind of what we want to disclose. A big chunk of information is available in our reference document, and you might be able to recalculate all this.

Like most banks, of course, the relative importance of our secured funding has grown over the last few years, although it still remains, I mean, I wouldn't say below the radar, but not that important. I understand it's a growing concern, so we have to make up our mind on what we want to disclose and explain, and I make a good note on that.

On our doubtful loans, again, I cannot be very specific but it's due to – essentially, one specific situation, which is most public and not public, so I cannot on the specific situation. But it's not the signal of a large deterioration.
Okay, thank you.
Okay, the next question is from Kiri Vijayarajah from Barclays Capital. Please go ahead.

Yes, thank you. You've given us some detail on the new issuance of medium and long-term funding during the quarter. But just so I can reconcile the moves, I wonder if you can tell us how much medium and long-term financing actually matured during the quarter? And also what would be useful is, what was the spread on the MLT that matured during the quarter, so I can compare that to the 148 bps on your issuance? Thanks.

I think you have the split on page eight. Again, in broad terms, I think we did a little bit more than €2 billion in senior and secured. I think we provided the details down the road. We – let me just check what we've done, I think we did – sorry, I don't have this on top of my mind. €2.7 billion were SFH vehicle €2.1 billion in – I mean, two moves the same day, 18-months and five-years senior unsecured on the tap on the last one. And then we also are doing roughly €400 million to €500 million of structured products every month, and we intend to continue more or less, around this reason. As I said, we've done also €700 million of car loan securitization in Germany. These are the main items.

In terms of pricing, SFH through our covered bond program in January, we had 170 bps for ten-year. In terms of senior and secured, on top of my memory, it has also shown the change in the spreads for the quarter. We did it at 85 bps for 18-months and 222 bps for five-years, but we did adapt on the same one at 155 bps, so again, shows...

Sorry, can I just interrupt you there? I was actually interested in what matured during the quarter rather than the details, just to try and reconcile the moves. Because some of your disclosure, the 8.7 you issued, actually takes me to, into April, whereas the liabilities you've given there will take you to the thirty-first of March. I'm just trying to reconcile those moves, so it's actually the maturity date I was after. What matured during the quarter in terms of MLT financing?
I don't have this on top of my head, I'm sorry. I come back to you, answer will come back to you. I don't have this on top of my head, I'm sorry.
Okay, all right. Not to worry. Thanks.
We have a next question from Fleurhaben Hargoon (1:40:15) Deutsche Bank. Madame, please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. First of all, I just wanted to come back quickly to Guillaume's question earlier, because I just want to be sure that I understand your answer correctly. On the strong performance that you had this quarter in FIC, was it actually also partly driven by some inventory gains and some reversals? Or was it really just client driven?

And then very quickly on the cost of deleveraging, if I remember correctly, I think you had guided on your latest earnings call for around €500 million to €700 million losses on loan sales for the year 2012. And I just wanted to know if you keep this guidance? And also on the average discount on loan sales, I think you had guided for 5%, which is indeed in line with what you have achieved this quarter, so just wanted to know if you keep this guidance? Thank you.

These various points, I think on the deleveraging costs, Didier has been very clear, and I will reiterate this. Basically, the loss of revenues, it's not – we didn't say, again, that this has converted it was in 2012. We are just speaking about kind of run-rate type of loss. Revenue impact, probably €700 million to €800 million, compensated by the savings from costs, so that the net gross operating income in fact should be around €0.5 billion, €500 million, and this is confirmed.

This is kind of a run rate impact in a given year, not especially 2012, because it's a work in process. Discount on the disposal, here again, last year we were between 1% and 2%. This year we had budgeted 5%. We are below that figure if you take into account both the legacy and then on the loan sales. We are closer to 5% if you take the loan sales, and so we are in line with what we announced at the beginning of this year.
On fixed income, Didier, if you want?

Just to add to right again, as I've said, first start, the start of the year was extremely strong due to market parameter convergence, so you can call that inventory, but there was really some benefit on the trading side. But also the same kind of assessments on the commercial fronts with the sales figures, let's say, that we've seen also good activity across the quarter.

And so I think that this is something that in my view is a good signal of the performance that the platform can extract from these – from our account base. And also, I hope that this will improve thanks with the organization that we are started to implement. So let's say part of the almost €1 billion is linked to inventories or to market parameter convergence. As I've said, don't multiple that by 4, but also let's say, we have seen a good performance from the commercial side on the fixed income side across the platform.

Back on your previous question, because I don't like to let questions unanswered voluntarily. I think the debt which has matured over the last four months is between €8 billion and €10 billion. Hans (1:43:21) will come back to you with a more precise figure. But if I made a calculation on a piece of paper, back of the envelope calculation for you, €8 billion to €10 billion.
We have a question Mariel Guarez (1:43:35), HSBC. Madame, please go ahead.

Good afternoon. Can you please comment a bit more on the performance of the equity business? And also do you think there could be in the performance potentially some impact from the job cuts occurring in this business? Thank you.
Let Didier answer. Can you repeat your second question?
Do you think that there could be in the performance in the equity revenues some impact from the job cuts that are occurring in this business?
Yeah, we'll let Didier answer.

I think, well, the performance that we've seen in the first quarter, I'd say, were satisfactory. And what we've seen that we have seen already in commercial activities on the foreign structured products, while it is a dynamism, was maybe a little bit more subdued, was on the listed products side.

Regarding as I said the impact of the job cuts, that's across the board as we've said for the business, located in Paris, most of that is starting beginning in the second quarter. So within the first quarter, it was more into market environment, let's say, overall and using that your business. Volumes were okay, but not as strong as we could have expected, and thus, let's say, we have all the secured concerning our leadership position.

But maybe also you should bear in mind that maybe compared to some of our peers, Q1 last year was a little bit stronger than most of the average. So let's say to be down 25% almost compared to last year, and up 60% compared to Q4, in our view show the strengths of our franchise.
Thank you.
The next question is from Andrew Lim, Espirito Santo [Execution Noble Ltd.]. Sir, please go ahead.

Good afternoon. Sorry to ask this, but could you quantify the inventory gains in your FIC trading, quite frankly? And then I've got a number of capital questions. You've given the benefit from deleveraging of your non-core businesses of 50 bps to 100 bps, and previously you've indicated 100 bps. Is that an implicit downgrade or is that just reflecting uncertainty on what kind of benefit you could achieve there?

And then could you give more color on what kind of businesses you could sell there? I mean, if I look at what they could be, it doesn't seem to tally with the improvements on the Core Tier 1 ratio, if I try and figure out what kind of capital gains or capital relief you could achieve there.

And then, two other questions. The 70 bps improvement from deleveraging SG CIB, to what extent is that dependent on achieving book values in line with fair values? I'm alluding here to the U.S. RMBS CDOs in the legacy asset portfolio, where there's a delta there of about 0.8 billion. If your book value does go down to the fair value, and you realize a 0.8 billion loss there, does that impact on that 70 bps improvement targets there?
And then lastly, just a technical question, do you have capital deductions on the Basel 3 applicable to your legacy asset portfolio? Thank you very much

I'm sorry, I'm not sure I got all your questions. I understand your questions regarding the size of the disposal, 50 bps to 100 bps versus 100 bps before. I understand your question – I think I understand your question on the 70 bps impact and the relationship with the value of our assets, but I didn't get your second and last point, sorry.

The last one, are there capital deductions on the Basel 3 with respect to the legacy asset portfolio? And then with respect to the 50 bps to 100 bps improvement for the non-core businesses, can you give some color about what kind of businesses you'd be expected to sell there? And what kind of capital gains that you would be able to expect from those sales? Thank you.

Okay, as I said in my introduction, the fact that we have – that our reaching 9.1% under Basel 3 fully loaded by the end of 2013 is not conditioned upon the disposal, doesn't mean that we want to stop the disposal process. The fact that we have moved from 100 bps to 50 bps to 100 bps, doesn't mean that we have changed our strategic plan. It just means that we are more considerate of the timetable, and we'll do what is doable under good conditions between now and end of 2013. And again, objective is 100 bps, but we are conscious of the time, and we don't want to do de-stressing, basically.

Second, what kind of businesses, again, I might refer you to what has been said by the group in 2010 regarding businesses, which are considered core and businesses which are called synergetic. And of course, that's probably a good indication of where we want to put our efforts in terms of disposal.

The 70 bps, again, you have to have in mind that even being a little bit simplistic, under Basel 3, every euro stuck in – or every dollar stuck in legacy asset, we've got more or less $1 or €1 of capital. It's as simple as that. So whenever you sell one of the assets, you gain on the capital front.

So in terms of Basel 3 trajectory, these legacy assets cost us €4 billion end of last year. And we expect it to be to €2.5 billion by the end of 2013. And we have done already a big part of this move this quarter, close to 25 bps I mean, 20 – whatever, 22 bps or 23 bps in legacy assets related on the one hand to disposal, and on the other hand to cracking. And we continue to do that, and we're quite confident, and that's basically it.

I'm sorry, could you quantify the inventory gains in FIC trading? And then that last technical question as to whether you include any kind of capital reductions on the Basel 3 for the legacy asset portfolio?
Didier will answer this. I'm not sure I got your question. Didier?

I'm not sure I get your question because on the inventory gain or whatever you call them, let's say, I was talking more about market parameters normally based. For the legacy asset, let's say the inventories are not in the performance of the core business, so the fixed income at almost €1 billion, and was not impacted by any improvement in valuation of the legacy assets.

You can, what you aim for that – to better assess, let's say, what to place on these instruments, you have full detail in the appendices. But don't mix let's say inventory gain, whatever, on the commercial assets, which are non-core, with the performance of the core bank on the fixed income side. I think this is what you were asking.
Okay. Thank you.
The last question is from Benoît Pétrarque of Kepler Capital Markets. Sir, please go ahead.

Good afternoon. Benoît from Kepler. Just to come back on the deleveraging of the legacy, I was quite surprised to have not seen more deleveraging in this quarter given the market was quite receptive. Could you have done more deleveraging without booking losses this quarter, or just prefer to keep deleveraging for just, for later? Just trying to understand why you have not done more, especially in January and February? Thanks.

Just to reiterate what I said in my initial presentation, the objective of the deleveraging was not to reach headline figures, which were as massive as possible. What we did last quarter was to split our legacy assets portfolio in two buckets, one investment grade, and one non-investment-grade. Or to be even more blunt, money good and money bad assets.

On the money good front, that's where you can make big figures, but it doesn't make sense most of the time, because these assets are providing very important yields, so a significant positive carry and very limited capital relief impact. So we continue to do some, depending on market conditions, depending on liquidity pressure, and so on and so forth, but it's not a priority for us. So we are not searching for volumes.

The objective, and it's very straightforward for Didier and for myself, is to make sure that whatever we do provides capital relief under Basel 3. That's why it is very efficient from a Basel 3 perspective. What we've done this quarter, the €0.5 billion disposal of money bad assets and the cracking of CDOs provided more than 20 bps under Basel 3, which compares only to 10 bps under Basel 2.5. So our ratios are still under Basel 2.5, so that's really the name of the game.

From my perspective, I think it's easier to free up the 20 bps or 25 bps of Basel 3 capital than just selling assets at a distressed price for the pleasure of seeing assets at a distressed price. So that's what we have in mind, this is our management intention over the next 18 months, and that's how we want to get to the 70 bps deleveraging target to put in our roadmap for Basel 3. Is it clear, Benoît?

Just on the non-investment-grade sales of bad assets, are you – kind of – did you reach a kind of limit where you're now if you are selling more – I understand it will be less and less. But if you are selling more, will that cost you also? You will have less impact on the capital?

I will let Didier comment on that, but the arbitrage is really this one. On the one hand, you can have P&L impact, on the other hand, a capital relief impact, and you have to make some arbitrage between this. Here again, the decision we made was to ask the team, which is on the ground dealing with these assets, to make sure they were targeting the Basel 3 capital relief impact is number one objective. And then, if they can do this with a limited general impact, and so on and so forth, but that really is a priority list that we have provided them with.

I think maybe to add a bit, some flavor to what Bertrand said. Let's say, what we are doing also in terms of settling of these legacy assets. As we said, it's cracking, cracking, I think we were maybe among the first to discuss about that. You've seen that currently, that's just some large CIBs are looking for such assets to crack and to get some – to extract some more value in their P&L. As you've seen, for example, for the major main street sale that took place last year, last week, sorry.

So what we believe we can do is, first, we can do that by our own. It's a way for us, let's say, and it takes some time in terms of execution, but we are ahead of our schedule in terms of our roadmaps under Basel 2.5 and Basel 3, so we can continue to work on it. And we will do that, rather do, let's say. We are optimizing, let's say, the financial impact by extracting more value, cracking certain of the TU (1:55:45) that we can do before selling the underlying assets. And doing that, let's say, we will be able to have sizable capital belief, while let's say having a better, let's say, management, also the value for our shareholders.

And this is what we, let's say, we have decided to do entering to this year. So you won't see let's say massive figures, because also on the money good assets, as Bertrand said, we made a big effort last year in Q3 and Q4. Now, we feel that they are not consuming that much retail liquidity and capital, and we can get some carry from that on the so-called money bad. We have some restructuring to do and we are working on it, so we're doing some of the players in the Street for some parties. We do that on our own and we feel that it's much better for our shareholders to manage that let's say in the coming quarters.
All right, thank you very much.

If not, I think its 3 p.m. Paris time. So thank you very much for your attention and patience. I think myself, Didier, everybody around the table, and the Investor Relations team is at your disposal should you have any other questions or requesting clarification. Many thanks again, and I wish you a very happy afternoon. Thank you. Bye.
Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the conference call. Thank you all for your participation. You may now disconnect.
